query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
1 Guardando nel suo Figlio con l’Amore 2 che l’uno e l’altro etternalmente spira, 3 lo primo e ineffabile Valore
4 quanto per mente e per loco si gira 5 con tant’ ordine fé, ch’esser non puote 6 sanza gustar di lui chi ciò rimira.
query.result:
1 Looking in his Son with Love 2 who the one and the other eternally breathes, 3 the first and ineffable Value
4 as much as by mind and by place it turns 5 with such order did, that being cannot 6 without tasting of him who that looks.

7 Raise then, reader, to the high wheels 8 with me the sight, straight to that part 9 where the one motion and the other strikes each other;
10 and there begins to wander in the art 11 of that master who within himself loves it, 12 so much that the eye never leaves it.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
13 Vedi come da indi si dirama 14 l’oblico cerchio che i pianeti porta, 15 per sodisfare al mondo che li chiama.
query.result: 13 See how from there it branches 14 the oblique circle that carries the planets, 15 to satisfy the world that calls them.

16 That if their road were not crooked, 17 much virtue in heaven would be in vain, 18 and almost every power down here dead;
19 and if from the straight more or less distant 20 the departure were, it would be much lacking 21 and down and up of the worldly order.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
22 Or ti riman, lettor, sovra ’l tuo banco, 23 dietro pensando a ciò che si preliba, 24 s’esser vuoi lieto assai prima che stanco.
query.result: 22 Now you remain, reader, over your bench, 23 behind thinking of that which is coveted, 24 if you want to be very happy before being tired.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
25 Messo t’ho innanzi: omai per te ti ciba; 26 ché a sé torce tutta la mia cura 27 quella materia ond’ io son fatto scriba.

Please translate each line literally into English.
28 Lo ministro maggior de la natura, 29 che del valor del ciel lo mondo imprenta 30 e col suo lume il tempo ne misura,
31 con quella parte che sù si rammenta 32 congiunto, si girava per le spire 33 in che più tosto ognora s’appresenta;
34 e io era con lui; ma del salire 35 non m’accors’ io, se non com’ uom s’accorge, 36 anzi ’l primo pensier, del suo venire.

Please translate each line literally into English.
37 È Bëatrice quella che sì scorge 38 di bene in meglio, sì subitamente 39 che l’atto suo per tempo non si sporge.
query.result: 37 It is Beatrice who so perceives 38 of good into better, so suddenly 39 that her act by time does not protrude

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
40 Quant’ esser convenia da sé lucente 41 quel ch’era dentro al sol dov’ io entra’mi, 42 non per color, ma per lume parvente!
43 Perch’ io lo ’ngegno e l’arte e l’uso chiami, 44 sì nol direi che mai s’imaginasse; 45 ma creder puossi e di veder si brami.
query.result:
40 How much being was fitting, self‑luminous 41 that which was inside the sun where I entered, 42 not for that, but for seeming light!
43 Because I engage it and the art and the use I call, 44 so I would not say that it ever imagined itself; 45 but to believe you could and to see you desire.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
46 E se le fantasie nostre son basse 47 a tanta altezza, non è maraviglia; 48 ché sopra ’l sol non fu occhio ch’andasse.

Please translate each line literally into English.
49 Tal era quivi la quarta famiglia 50 de l’alto Padre, che sempre la sazia, 51 mostrando come spira e come figlia.
query.result: 49 Such was here the fourth family 50 of the high Father, who always satisfies it, 51 showing how it breathes and how it is a daughter

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
52 E Bëatrice cominciò: «Ringrazia, 53 ringrazia il Sol de li angeli, ch’a questo 54 sensibil t’ha levato per sua grazia».
query.result: 52 And Beatrice began: «Thank, 53 thank the Sun of the angels, that to this 54 sensible has lifted you by its grace».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
55 Cor di mortal non fu mai sì digesto 56 a divozione e a rendersi a Dio 57 con tutto ’l suo gradir cotanto presto,
58 come a quelle parole mi fec’ io; 59 e sì tutto ’l mio amore in lui si mise, 60 che Bëatrice eclissò ne l’oblio.
query.result:
55 Heart of mortal was never so digestible 56 to divination and to render oneself to God 57 with all its desire so soon,
58 as to those words I made; 59 and so all my love in him was placed, 60 that Beatrice eclipsed into oblivion.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
61 Non le dispiacque; ma sì se ne rise, 62 che lo splendor de li occhi suoi ridenti 63 mia mente unita in più cose divise.
query.result: 61 It did not displease her; but she laughed about it, 62 that the splendor of her laughing eyes 63 my mind united in many things divided.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
64 Io vidi più folgór vivi e vincenti 65 far di noi centro e di sé far corona, 66 più dolci in voce che in vista lucenti:
67 così cinger la figlia di Latona 68 vedem talvolta, quando l’aere è pregno, 69 sì che ritenga il fil che fa la zona.
query.result:
64 I saw more living and victorious splendor 65 to make of us a centre and of itself a crown, 66 sweeter in voice than bright in sight:
67 thus surrounds the daughter of Latona 68 we see sometimes, when the air is full, 69 so that it holds the thread that makes the zone.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
76 Poi, sì cantando, quelli ardenti soli 77 si fuor girati intorno a noi tre volte, 78 come stelle vicine a’ fermi poli,
79 donne mi parver, non da ballo sciolte, 80 ma che s’arrestin tacite, ascoltando 81 fin che le nove note hanno ricolte.
query.result:
76 Then, yes singing, those burning suns 77 were turned themselves around us three times, 78 like stars near the fixed poles,
79 women seem to me, not loosened by dance, 80 but that they stop themselves silently, listening 81 until the nine notes have been gathered.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
82 E dentro a l’un senti’ cominciar: «Quando 83 lo raggio de la grazia, onde s’accende 84 verace amore e che poi cresce amando,
85 multiplicato in te tanto resplende, 86 che ti conduce su per quella scala 87 u’ sanza risalir nessun discende;
88 qual ti negasse il vin de la sua fiala 89 per la tua sete, in libertà non fora 90 se non com’ acqua ch’al mar non si cala.

Please translate each line literally into English.
91 Tu vuo’ saper di quai piante s’infiora 92 questa ghirlanda che ’ntorno vagheggia 93 la bella donna ch’al ciel t’avvalora.
query.result: 91 You want to know of which plants it is flowered 92 this garland that wanders around 93 the beautiful woman who to the sky ennobles you

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
94 Io fui de li agni de la santa greggia 95 che Domenico mena per cammino 96 u’ ben s’impingua se non si vaneggia.
query.result: 94 I was of the lambs of the holy flock 95 that Domenico leads along the path 96 where good is impinged if it does not go mad.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
97 Questi che m’è a destra più vicino, 98 frate e maestro fummi, ed esso Alberto 99 è di Cologna, e io Thomas d’Aquino.
query.result: 97 This one who is to my right more near, 98 brother and master we were, and that one Alberto 99 is of Cologna, and I Thomas of Aquinas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
100 Se sì di tutti li altri esser vuo’ certo, 101 di retro al mio parlar ten vien col viso 102 girando su per lo beato serto.
query.result: 100 If so of all the others to be you want certainly, 101 from behind to my speech you come with the face, 102 turning up through the blessed wreath.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
103 Quell’ altro fiammeggiare esce del riso 104 di Grazïan, che l’uno e l’altro foro 105 aiutò sì che piace in paradiso.
query.result: 103 That other flaming emerges from the laughter 104 of Grazïan, that the one and the other hole 105 helped so that it pleases in paradise

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
106 L’altro ch’appresso addorna il nostro coro, 107 quel Pietro fu che con la poverella 108 offerse a Santa Chiesa suo tesoro.
query.result: 106 The other who nearby adorns our choir, 107 that Peter was who with the little poor woman 108 offered to Holy Church his treasure.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
109 La quinta luce, ch’è tra noi più bella, 110 spira di tale amor, che tutto ’l mondo 111 là giù ne gola di saper novella:
112 entro v’è l’alta mente u’ sì profondo 113 saver fu messo, che, se ’l vero è vero, 114 a veder tanto non surse il secondo.
query.result:
109 The fifth light, which is among us most beautiful, 110 breathes such love, that all the world 111 there down in the throat of new knowledge:
112 inside there is the high mind that so deep 113 knowledge was placed, that, if the true is true, 114 to see so much the second did not arise.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
115 Appresso vedi il lume di quel cero 116 che giù in carne più a dentro vide 117 l’angelica natura e ’l ministero.
query.result: 115 Afterwards you see the light of that candle 116 that down in flesh more inward saw 117 the angelic nature and the ministry

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
118 Ne l’altra piccioletta luce ride 119 quello avvocato de’ tempi cristiani 120 del cui latino Augustin si provide.
query.result: 118 In the other tiny light smiles 119 that lawyer of the Christian times 120 of whose Latin Augustine provides himself

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
121 Or se tu l’occhio de la mente trani 122 di luce in luce dietro a le mie lode, 123 già de l’ottava con sete rimani.
query.result: 121 Now if you draw the eye of the mind 122 of light in light behind my praises, 123 already of the eighth with thirst you remain

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
124 Per vedere ogne ben dentro vi gode 125 l’anima santa che ’l mondo fallace 126 fa manifesto a chi di lei ben ode.
query.result: 124 To see every good inside it enjoys 125 the holy soul that the deceitful world 126 makes manifest to those who hear its good

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
127 Lo corpo ond’ ella fu cacciata giace 128 giuso in Cieldauro; ed essa da martiro 129 e da essilio venne a questa pace.
query.result: 127 The body where she was cast lies 128 down in Cieldauro; and she from martyr 129 and from exile came to this peace

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
130 Vedi oltre fiammeggiar l’ardente spiro 131 d’Isidoro, di Beda e di Riccardo, 132 che a considerar fu più che viro.
query.result: 130 See beyond flaming the ardent spirit 131 of Isidore, of Bede and of Richard, 132 who to consider was more than a man

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
133 Questi onde a me ritorna il tuo riguardo, 134 è ’l lume d’uno spirto che ’n pensieri 135 gravi a morir li parve venir tardo:
136 essa è la luce etterna di Sigieri, 137 che, leggendo nel Vico de li Strami, 138 silogizzò invidïosi veri».
query.result:
133 From these, your regard returns to me, 134 it is the light of a spirit that in thoughts 135 heavy to die seemed to come late:
136 it is the eternal light of Sigieri, 137 who, reading in the Alley of the Stems, 138 syllogized envious truths.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
139 Indi, come orologio che ne chiami 140 ne l’ora che la sposa di Dio surge 141 a mattinar lo sposo perché l’ami,
142 che l’una parte e l’altra tira e urge, 143 tin tin sonando con sì dolce nota, 144 che ’l ben disposto spirto d’amor turge;
145 così vid’ ïo la gloriosa rota 146 muoversi e render voce a voce in tempra 147 e in dolcezza ch’esser non pò nota
148 se non colà dove gioir s’insempra.
query.result:
139 Then, like a clock that calls us 140 in the hour that the bride of God rises 141 to morning the husband because you love him,
142 that the one part and the other pulls and urges, 143 tin tin sounding with such sweet note, 144 that the well‑disposed spirit of love churns;
145 thus I saw the glorious wheel 146 moving and giving voice to voice in temper 147 and in sweetness that being cannot be noted
148 if not there where joy is always.
